Instructions: Mix dry ingredients.  Add milk, egg and oil.  Mix only until ingredients are combined.  Spread batter in a nonstick 9"x9" pan or fill muffin pans 2/3 full.  Applesauce can be omitted but it keeps cornbread moist.  Bake at 400° for 14-16 minutes.  For muffins, bake for 12-14 minutes.

Name: Popovers
Instructions: Put all ingredients in blender.  Mix on low speed for 30 seconds.  Pour into nonstick muffin pans.  Bake at 450° for 15 minutes.  Reduce heat to 350° and bake 20-25 minutes or until firm and brown.  A few minutes before removing from oven, prick popovers with a fork to allow steam to escape.  For crispy popovers, turn off oven and leave popovers in oven with door ajar for 30 minutes.  Serve hot.

Name: Spoon Bread
Instructions: Sift dry ingredients together, add milk gradually, drop in egg.  Add fat and beat mixture thoroughly.  Bake in greased baking dishes at 375° for 30 to 45 minutes.

Name: Hominy Custard
Instructions: Mix hominy with beaten eggs, milk, butter and salt.  Pour into buttered baking dish and bake in pan of hot water until firm (about 30 minutes) at 350°.  Grated cheese may also be added.

Name: Hominy Pudding
Instructions: Mix the ingredients and put in buttered custard cups.  Set in a pan of water and bake at 350° till set like a custard.

Name: Potato Soup
Instructions: Cook potatoes and onion for 15 minutes in boiling water.  Add seasonings and cream.  Heat.  Garnish with chopped parsley.

Name: Cream of Corn Soup
Instructions: Cut corn from cob or take out of can/freezer.  Add water and boil until tender.  If in a hurry, put the corn though a blender or food processor before cooking.  Mix butter and flour together well.  When corn is tender, add butter/flour mixture.  Season to taste and allow it to boil.  Add sweet cream just before serving.

Name: Cream of Cucumber Soup
Instructions: Peel cucumbers, cut in slices and simer in boiling salted water for about 15 minutes.  Puree cucumbers in blender with some of the cooking liquid-start with 1 Tbs and add more as necessary.  Scald milk with the onion in a double boiler then remove onion.  Add cucumbers, then add the butter and flour creamed together with salt and pepper.  A dash of Worcestershire sauce or a few grains of nutmeg may also be used.  Garnish with parsley or chives.  Serve with several croutons floated on the top of each bowl.

Name: Cream of Carrot Soup
Instructions: Combine carrots, flour, butter, salt and pepper.  Boil milk and stir carrot mixture in.  Simeer for 5 minutes.

Name: Cream of Potato Soup
Instructions: Mix potatoes, butter, flour, salt and pepper with milk and cook until creamy.

Name: Cream of Spinach Soup
Instructions: Put spinach to cook in a saucepan of boiling water.  Boil rapidly, uncovered, until tender (about 2 minutes).  Drain in a colander and run cold water through it.  Chop fine.  While spinach is cooking, prepare soup by cooking together butter and flour with hot milk.  Add salt.  Season with pepper and nutmeg.  Add spinach and run through blender to puree.  Serve hot.

Name: Corn Chowder
Instructions: Heat butter in frying pan.  Add flour and water.  Add onions and potatoes and cook until potatoes are soft.  Add corn and milk.  Cook for 10 minutes.  Season to taste.

Name: Vegetable Chowder
Instructions: Add enough water to cook potatoes and carrots and cook together.  Do not drain off water.  Brown the chopped onion in butter.  Add the cooked vegetables, liquid and tomatoes to the browned onion.  Add salt and milk.  Heat but do not boil.

Name: Salmon Chowder
Instructions: Brown salt pork or bacon, add onion and cook until soft and yellow.  Add potatoes, cover with water and cook until tender but not mushy.  Add salmon, milk, butter and salt.  Bring to boiling point.  In each bowl, crush 1 to 2 crackers, pour in soup and sprinkle with chopped parsley

Name: Clam Chowder
Instructions:
Fry pork very crisp.  Add onions and fry, constantly cutting them with a spoon and being careful to to burn.  

Put pork, onions and fat from frying into chowder kettle, add the diced potatoes, clam water and boiling water to cover.  When potatoes are soft, add clams from which the black part has been removed and which have been put through a meat chopper.  Cook for 5 to 10 minutes.  Add seasonings and scalded milk.  Put crackers and butter into a tureen.  Pour hot chowder over them and serve at once, very hot.

Name: Old-Fashioned Applesauce
Instructions: Put the apples and the water into a saucepan.  Cover tightly and cook rapidly without stirring until they begin to boil.  The apples should be cooked to a mush by this time.  Add the sugar and cook for 2 to 3 minutes longer, stirring constantly.  More or less water may be used depending on stiffness desired.

Name: Banana Pudding
Instructions: In saucepan, combine milk, sugar, eggs and vanilla.  Make a soft custard by cooking gently (do not boil!) until thick.  Stir constantly.  Slice bananas, arranging them alternately with wafers in casserole or baking dish.  Pour custard over this and place marshmallows cut in halves over top.  Put in oven for a few minutes to brown.

Name: Peach Pudding
Instructions: Butter a pudding dish and place canned peach halves in the bottom of it.  In a mixing bowl, combine milk, sugar, egg, butter, baking powder and flour until a batter forms.  Pour over peaches and bake at 350° until nicely browned.  Serve with cream.

Name: Feta Brunch Bake
Instructions:
Preheat broiler.  Place bell pepper on foil-lined broiler pan.  Broil, 4 inches from heat, 15 to 20 minutes or until blackened on all sides, turning every 5 minutes with tongs.  Place in a paper bag; close bag and set aside to cool about 15 to 20 minutes.  To peel pepper, cut around core, twist and remove.  Cut in half and peel off skin with paring knife; rinse under cold water to remove seeds.  Cut into 1/2" pieces.

To blanch spinach, place 1 quart water in 2-quart saucepan over high heat; bring to a boil.  Add spinach.  Return to a boil; boil 2 to 3 minutes or until crisp-tender.  Drain; immediately plunge into cold water.  Drain; let stand until cool enough to handle.  Squeeze spinach to remove excess water; finely chop.

Preheat oven to 400°.  Grease 1-quart baking dish.  Beat eggs in large bowl with electric mixer at medium speed until foamy.  Stir in bell pepper, spinach, cheese, onion, parsley, dill weed and black pepper.  Pour egg mixture into prepared dish.  Bake 20 minutes or until set.  Let stand 5 minutes before serving.  Garnish as desired.

Name: Individual Spinach and Bacon Quiches
Instructions:
Preheat oven to 350°.  Spray 10 muffin pan cups with nonstick cooking spray.  Cook bacon in large skillet over medium-high heat until crisp.  Drain; let cool and crumble.

In same skillet, cook and stir onion in remaining bacon fat 5 minutes or until tender.  Add spinach, pepper, nutmeg and salt.  Cook and stir over medium heat about 3 minutes or until liquid evaporates.  Remove from heat and stir in bacon; let cool.  

Combine ricotta, mozzarelly and Parmesan cheese in large bowl.  Add eggs; stir until well blended.  Add cooled spinach mixture; mix well.  Divide mixture evely among prepared muffin cups.  Bake 40 minutes or until filling is set.  Let stand 10 minutes.  Run thin knife around edges to release.  Serve hot or refrigerate and serve cold.

Name: Thai Broccoli Salad
Instructions:
Combine peanut butter, sugar, hot water, lime juice, soy sauce, sesame oil and red pepper flakes until well blended; set aside.

Heat vegetable oil in large skilled over medium-high heat.  Add broccoli, red pepper, green onions and garlic.  Stir-fry 3 to 4 minutes until vegetables are tender-crisp.  Remove from heat and stir in peanut butter mixture.  Serve warm or at room temperature.

Name: Peanut Butter and Banana Cookies
Instructions: Preheat oven to 375°.  Beat butter in large bowl until creamy.  Add banana and peanut butter; beat until smooth.  Blend in apple juice concentrate, egg and vanilla.  Beat in flour, baking soda and salt.  Stir in chopped peanuts.  Drop rounded tablespoonfuls of dough 2" apart onto lightly greased cookie sheets; tope each with one peanut, if desired.  Bake 8 minutes or until set.  Cool completely on wire racks.  Store in tightly covered container.

Name: Oatmeal Almond Bars
Instructions: Preheat oven to 350°.  Place almonds on ungreased cookie sheet; bake 8 to 10 minutes or until golden brown.  Set aside.  Do not turn off oven.  Combine egg whites, honey, cinnamon and salt in large bowl; stir until well blended.  Add oats and toasted almonds; stir until well blended.  Drop dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto ungreased nonstick cookie sheets.  Bake 12 minutes or until lightly browned.  Remove to wire racks; cool completely.

Name: Hearty Homemade Beef and Vegetable Soup
Instructions:
Defrost meat if necessary.  Meanwhile, heat oil in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup ot over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop onion, adding to pot as you chop.  Add partially defrosted meat, raise heat to medium-high and cook, breaking up meat until it has completely browned, 7 to 8 minutes.  Drain.  Add garlic to beef.  Drain beans and add along with broth, tomatoes with their juices, tomato paste and 2 cups water.  Raise heat to high and stir well.

Add corn, peas and seasoning.  Cover and continue to cook until the soup starts to boil.  Reduce the heat to low and simmer, stirring occasionally, to blend the flavors, 5 to 7 minutes.  Ladle into soup bowls and serve.

Name: Grandmother Rose's Mulligan
Instructions:
Bring 2-1/2 quarts lightly salted water to a boil in a covered 4-1/2 quart or larger Dutch oven or soup pot.  When the water reaches a rapid boil, add the pasta and cook, uncovered, until firm-tender following package directions.

Meanwhile, defrost beef in need.  Heat oil in a 4-1/2 quart or larger soup pot over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Add the partially defrosted meat to pot, raise heat to medium-high and cook, breaking up meat, until it has completely browned, 7 to 8 minutes.  Drain.  

Add tomato-vegetable juice, chili powder, sugar and black pepper.  Stir well and bring the soup to a boil.  Reduce the heat to medium-low and cook at a slow boil to blend the flavors 5 to 7 minutes.  When the macaroni si done, drain.  To serve, spoon some macaroni into each bowl and ladle the soup over it.

Name: Beef and Barley Soup
Instructions: Pour the two broths into a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot.  Add 3 cups water and bring to a boil over high heat.  While the liquid is heating, slice the carrots, adding them to the pot as you slice.  Peel and chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Add the beef and barley.  When soup begins to boil, reduce heat to medium-low.  Simmer, covered, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking, until the vegetables and barley are tender, about 45 minutes.

Name: Mindless Meatball Minestrone
Instructions:
Pour the two broths into a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot and place over high heat.  While liquid is heating, add the frozen vegetables, tomatoes, meatballs and pasta.  Cover the pot and bring to a boil.  This will take about 10 minutes. 

While soup is heating, rinse and drain beans.  When soup comes to a boil, uncover it and stir well. (The pasta might stick to the bottom.  If so, scrape the bottom of the pot with a wooden spoon to loosen it).  Add the beans, Italian seasoning and garlic powder and reduce the heat to medium or medium-high (to maintain vigorous boil).  Stir frequently until the pasta is tender, about 3 minutes.  Serve at once, garnishing each bowl with 1 Tbs. Parmesan cheese

Name: Hot Dog and Baked Bean Soup
Instructions:
Heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Cut the franks into 1/4" thick slices and add them to the pot.  Cook until the franks start to brown, 2 to 3 minutes.  Add baked beans with their juice and the broth, chili powder and mustard.  Stir well.  Raise the heat to high and bring the soup to a boil.  Then reduce the heat to medium to maintain a moderate boil.  

Stem, seed and coarsely chop the green pepper and set it aside.  Continue to boil the soup to blend the flavors, about 10 minutes.  Add the green pepper to the pot in the last 5 minutes of cooking.  Serve at once.

Name: Cure-all Chicken Soup
Instructions:
Bring 2 cups lightly salted water to a boil in a 2 quart saucepan.  While the water is heating, defrost chicken if needed.  When water comes to a boil, add rice, stir and reduce heat to low.  Cover the pan and simmer until the rice is tender, about 20 minutes.  

Meanwhile, heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart or larger Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peel the onion and finely chop, adding to the pot as you chop.  Cut the chicken into bite-size pieces, adding them to the pot as you cut.  When all of the chicken is in the pot, raise the heat to medium-high.  Cook, stirring, until the chicken is almost cooked through, about 4 minutes. 

Peel and coarsely chop the carrots, adding them to the pot as you chop.  Coarsely dice the celery, adding as you go.  Add the garlic and ginger to the pot.  Continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until the celery is crisp-tender, about 2 minutes.

Add the broth to the pot, raise the heat to high and bring the soup to a boil.  Then reduce heat to medium and cook at a moderate boil to combine the flavors, 5 minutes.  Season with black pepper.  To serve, spoon some rice into each bowl and top with the soup.

Name: Turkey Vegetable soup with Brown Rice
Instructions:
Bring 2-1/4 cups lightly salted water to a boil in a covered 2 quart saucepan.  Add the rice, stir and reduce the heat to low.  Cover the pan and simmer until all the water is absorbed, about 30 minutes.  While rice is cooking, heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart or larger Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peall and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Cook, stirring occasionally, until the onion starts to soften, about 2 minutes.

Add garlic to pot along with cabbage, broth, tomatoes with their juice, bay leaf, thyme, black pepper, soy sauce and Worcestershire sauce.  Bring the soup to a boil.  Reduce the heat to medium-low to maintain a slow boil.  If the frozen vegetables have ice crystals, pour them into a colander and rinse with warm water.  Add the vegetables and turkey cubes to the pot and simmer until ready to serve.  When rice is done, place about 1/2 cup in each soup bowl, spoon soup over the rice and serve.

Name: Mini Ravioli Soup
Instructions:
Heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  While the oil is heating, peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Cook, stirring occasionally, until tender, about 3 minutes. 

Rinse, pat dry and slice the mushrooms, discarding any tough stems.  Add the mushrooms to the pot and cook until they begin to release their liquid, about 2 minutes.  Add the garlic, broth, tomatoes with their juice, Worcestershire sauce and basil.  Raise the heat to high, cover the pot and bring the soup to a boil.  

When the soup is at a rolling boil, add the ravioli.  When it returns to a boil, cook until ravioli are just tender, 3 to 4 minutes.  Serve at once, passing Parmesan cheese around the table to sprinkle on top.

Name: Pasta e Fagioli
Instructions:
Heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Cook, stirring occasionally, while peeling and slicing the carrots into 1/4" thick rounds.  Add the carrots to the pot and cook, stirring frequently, until the begin to soften, about 3 minutes.

Add the garlic, broth, tomatoes with their juice and Italian seasoning to the pot.  Cover, raise the heat to high and bring the soup to a boil.  When the broth comes to a boil, add the macaroni and cook, uncovered, at a rolling boil for 7 minutes.  Meanwhile, rinse and drain the beans.  Add the beans and bring the soup back to a boil.  Continue to cook until the macaroni is tender, about 3 minutes more.  Season the soup with pepper and serve, sprinkling the Parmesan cheese on top.

Name: Refried Bean Soup
Instructions:
Heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart Ductch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding to the pot as you chop.  Seed and coarsely chop the bell peper, adding to the pot as you chop.  Raise the heat to medium-high and cook until the vegetables are tender, 2 to 3 minutes.

Add the garlic to pot.  Stir in the broth and tomaotes with their juice.  Raise the heat to high.  Rinse and drin the black beans and kidney beans and add them to the soup pot.  Add the refried beans and cumin.  Stir well.  Cover the pot and let the soup come to a boil.  Reduce the heat to low and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the soup is heated through and the flavors have blended, 5 to 7 minutes.  Season with black pepper and serve.

Name: Loaded Baked Potato Soup
Instructions:
Melt butter in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Meanwhile, peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Raise the heat to medium-high and cook until the onion begins to soften, about 2 minutes.  Meanwhile, cut the baked potatoes in half. 

Add the broth to the soup pot, raise the heat to high and bring to a boil.  When the broth boils, reduce the heat to medium.  Meanwhile, scoop the insides of the baked potatoes into a 2-quart or larger bowl, leaving a 1/4" thick shell.  Reserve skins for another use.  Cut the potato into bite-size pieces and add them to the pot.  

Add the milk and sour cream and stir well.  Add the salt and black pepper to taste to correct seasonings.  Cook until heated through, 3 to 5 minutes.  Serve at once, garnished with bacon bits and cheese if desired.

Name: Corn and Tomato Soup
Instructions:
Heat cream-style corn according to package directions.  Meanwhile, melt the butter in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Cook the onion, stirring occasionally, until slightly softened, about 3 minutes.  Add the garlic to the pot, stir, and cook for 30 seconds.  Add the broth, tomatoes with their juice, frozen corn kernels and the defrosted cream-style corn.  Season with black pepper.

Raise heat to high and bring the soup just to a boil, stirring occasionally.  Reduce heat to medium and cook at a moderate boil, stirring frequently, for 5 minutes.  If you are using corn muffins, cut them in half and place 2 halves in each soup bowl.  Ladle soup into bowls and serve.

Name: Sweet Onion Chowder
Instructions:
Cook bacon until crisp.  Set aside.  Meanwhile, heat oil in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peel the onions and coarsely chop them, adding them to the pot as you chop.  When all of the onions have been added, raise the heat to medium-high and cook, stirring frequently, until they are tender, about 6 minutes.

Add the garlic to the soup pot.  Cook, stirring, for 1 minute.  Add the stock and stir well, scraping the bottom of the pot to remove any brown bits.  Add the mashed potatoes, corn, bay leaves, thyme and black pepper. 

Cover the pot, raise the heat to high, and bring the soup to a boil.  Meanwhile, coarsely crumble the bacon and set it aside.  When the soup comes to a boil, remove the pot from the heat.  Remove the bay leaves and stir in the sour cream until it is well combined.  Serve at once, sprinkling the crumbled bacon on top.

Name: Budget Beef Stew
Instructions:
Place rack in the middle of the oven and preheat the oven to 300°.  Make sure all beef cubes are smaller than 1".  Place the beef in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or flameproof casserole that has a tight-fitting lid.  Sprinkle the salt, black pepper, basil and Worcestershire sauce evenly over the beef.  Sprinkle with garlic.

Peel and quarter the onions and scatter the pieces evely over the mixture (make sure onions are bite-size).  Peel the carrots and cut them into 1" pieces.  Add them to the pot.  Peel and quarter the potatoes and scatter the pices evenly over the mixture.  Add the tomatoes with their juice, scattering the tomatoes evely over the mixture.  Add 1/2 cup water.

Bake the stew, covered, for 2 hours.  Remove the pot from the oven and stir the stew gently so as not to break up the vegetables.  Continue to bake, covered, until the vegetables and meat are very tender, about 1 hour.

Remove the pot from the oven and place it on the stovetop over low heat.  Mix the cornstarch with the cold water in a jar that has a lid.  Cover the jar and shake it well to remove any lumps.  Pour the mixture, a little at a time, evely over the stew.  Stir gently, adding the cornstarch mixture as necessary until the liquid reaches the desired thickness, about 3 to 5 minutes.  Ladle the stew into large shallow bowls to serve.

Name: Simple Chicken Stew
Instructions:
Defrost chicken if necessary.  While chicken defrosts, heat the oil in a 4-1/2 quart Dutch oven or soup pot over medium heat.  Peel the onion and finely chop it, adding it to the pot as you chop.  Cut the partially defrosted or fresh chicken into bite-sized pieces, adding them to the pot as you cut.  When all the chicken has been added, raise the heat to medium-high and cook, stirring, until the chicken is almost cooked through, about 3 minutes.

Peel the carrots and cut it into 1/4" thick slices, adding them to the pot as you slice.  Finely chop the celery and add it to the pot.  Cook, stirring, until the vegetalbes are tender, about 3 minutes.

Add the broth and 4 cups water and raise the heat to high.  While liquid is heating, slice the flour tortillas into thin strips (1/2").  When the liquid is at a boil, add the stirps and cook until plumped up, 4 to 5 minutes.  (If the liquid begins to boil over, reduce the heat to medium to maintain a slow boil.)  When the tortillas are plump, remove the pot from the heat and let the stew stand for about 5 minutes to cool slightly.  To serve, divide the stew among four soup bowls.

Name: Shipwreck Skillet Dinner
Instructions:
Pour the broth and 1/4 cup water into a covered medium-size saucepan and bring to a boil.  Add the rice, stir and reduce the heat to low.  Cover the pan and simmer until rice is tender, about 20 minutes.

Meanwhile, defrost beef in needed.  Heat the oil in an extra-deep 12" skillet over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the skillet as you chop.  Add the beef to the skillet and cook, turning and breaking up the meat, until the beef is crumbled and brown, 7 to 8 minutes.

While the meat cooks, add the garlic to the skillet.  Add the Worcestershire sauce and seasoning salt.  Stem, seed and cut the bell pepper into bite-size pices, adding them to skillet as you chop.  Add the corn and stir well.

Continue to cook until green pepper is tender, about 2 minutes more.  Remove the skillet from the heat and set it aside until the rice is done if necessary.  Stir the rice into the beef mixture and season with black pepper.  Serve at once.

Name: Hungry Man's Macaroni
Instructions:
Defrost beef if necessary.  Meanwhile, heat oil in an extra-deep 12" skillet over medium heat.  Peel and coarsely chop the onion, adding it to the skillet as you chop.  Add the beef and cook, turning and breaking up the meat until it begins to crumble and brown, 5 to 6 minutes.  Drain.

Stem, seed and coarsely chop the bell pepper, adding it to the skillet as you chop.  Add the garlic to the skillet.  Add the broth, spaghetti sauce and pasta.  Stir until well mixed.  Cover and bring to a boil.  Cook at a moderate boil, stirring occasionally, until the pasta is tender, about 10 minutes (Cook 2 minutes more for softer pasta).  Serve at once, sprinkling each serving with about 1 Tbs. Parmesan cheese.

Name: Old-Fashioned Chicken and Dumplings
Instructions:
Rinse chicken, pat dry with paper towels and sprinkle chicken with salt and pepper.  Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.  Add chicken pieces to the pan and brown well on all sides, turning gently with tongs and being careful not to crowd the pan.  Remove chicken from the pan and set aside.  Discard fat from the pan.

Return the pan to the stove and melt butter over medium heat.  Add onion, carrots and celery and cook, stirring frequently, for 3 minutes or until onion is translucent.  Add flour and cook for 2 minutes, stirring constantly.  Add stock, parsley, herbes de Provence and bay leaf to the pan and bring to a boil.

Return chicken to the pan, cover and cook chicken over medium-low heat for 20-30 minutes or until chickenis cooked through.  While chicken simmers, prepare dumpling dough.  Combine flour, baking powder, salt, pepper and sage in a mixing bowl.  Cut butter using pastry blender, two knives or your fingertips until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.  Add milk and stir to blend.  Knead dough lightly on lightly floured counter then cut into 12 parts and make each part into a patty. 

Add peas to chicken mixture, remove and discard bay leaf and place dough rounds on top of chicken.  Cover the pan and cook for 15 minutes or until dumplings are puffed and cooked through.  Do not uncover pan while dumplings steam.  Serve immediately.

Name: Fancy Baked Chicken
Instructions:
Combine butter, cheese, garlic powder and salt in a shallow bowl.  Mix well.  Dip each piece of chicken in mixture. (Reserve remaining butter mixture).  Coat each chicken breast half with bread crumbs.  As you finish with each piece, place in a greased 9"x13" baking pan.  Spoon reserved butter mixture over top.  Bake, uncovered, at 350° for 45-60 minutes.

Variations:  Make nuggets.  Melt butter separate.  Combine cheese, salt and bread crumbs in another shallow bowl.  Dip in butter then in crumbs.  Bake at 400° for 10 minutes.

Name: Crunchy Creamy Chicken
Instructions:
Place chicken pieces in large stockpot.  Add water to cover about half the depth of the chicken.  Cover and simmer gently until chicken begins to fall off the bone.  Remove from hot broth and allow to cool.  When cool enough to handle, debone chicken.  Place meat in greased 9"x13" baking pan.

In a large mixing bowl, blend soup and sour cream.  Spread over chicken.  Melt butter in a small saucepan.  Stir in crushed crackers and sprinkle on top of chicken.  Bake uncovered at 350° for 30 minutes or until crumbs are brown and casserole is bubbly

Name: Lemon Snowflakes
Instructions: Combine cake mix, egg and cool whip in an electric mixer bowl.  Beat on medium speed until blended.  Batter will be very sticky.  Drop by teaspoonfuls into confectioners' sugar.  Roll lightly to coat.  Place on ungreased cookie sheet.  Keep cookies about 1" apart so they don't spread into each other.  Bake at 350° for 10-12 minutes or until lightly browned.

Name: Cherry Cream Cheese Tarts
Instructions: Blend cream cheese and butter until smooth in a mixing bowl.  Stir in flour just until blended.  Chill, covered, for one hour in the fridge.  Shape dough into 24-1" balls.  Press into ungreased mini muffin cups to make a shallow shell.  Spoon one tablespoon pie filling into each center.  Bake at 325° for 20-25 minutes.  Remove from muffin cups when they reach room temperature.

Name: Apple Butter Cookies
Instructions:
Place flour in a large mixing bowl.  Cut butter in chunks and place in bowl with flour.  Using a pastry cutter, cut butter into flour until the entire mixture resembles small peas.  Add water gradually, stirring as you go.  Stir in vanilla.  When the dough forms a baill, gather it all together.  Place on a lightly floured surface.  Roll out very thin.  Cut into 2-1/2" squares.

Place 1/2 tsp. apple butter on each square.  Pull 4 corners to center and pinch tightly together.  Place filled cookies on an ungreased baking sheet.  Bake at 375° for 13-15 minutes or until cookies are lightly browned.

Name: Spaghetti and Sauce
Instructions:
In a large pot, cook and stir the bulk Italian sausage with onion until the meat is brown, about 15 minutes.  Drain the fat.  Add remaining ingredients except spaghetti.  Bring sauce to a boil; reduce heat.  Partly cover and simmer for 1 hour, stirring occasionally.  After sauce has cooled, freeze the sauce in 9-cup containers.

To prepare: thaw sauce and heat in a medium saucepan.  Cook noodles according to package directions, drain and pour sauce over them.

Name: Barbecued Chicken
Instructions:
In a 1-gallon  freezer bag, combine all ingredients (spices together first, then add liquides, then chicken).  Freeze.

To prepare:  Thaw bag and remove chicken, reserving marinade.  Grill over medium hot coals 15 to 20 minutes, basting frequently with reserved marinade.

Name: Chili Hamburgers
Instructions:
Thoroughly mix all ingredients except buns.  Shape into 4 hamburger patties.  Wrap each in waxed paper and freeze in large freezer bag with waxed paper in between.

To prepare:  Thaw patties.  Grill or fry patties to desired pinkness in center.  Serve on warmed hamburger buns.

Name: Savory Beef
Instructions:
Cut beef into thin strips about 2" long.  Sprinkle beef with pepper and set meat aside in a cool place.  In a heavy skillet, saute mushrooms and onions in oil until golden, about 10 to 15 minutes.  Remove from the skillet.  Put meat in same skillet; cook and stir steak quickly on all sides until brown but still rare in the center, about 7 minutes.  Remove meat and set aside.  

Blend flour into drippings in skillet, gradually adding water and beef bouillon.  Bring to a boil.  Stir constantly until smooth and slightly thick.  Mix in tomato paste, dry mustard, oregano, dill weed and Worcestershire sauce.  Stir meat, mushrooms and onions into sauce.  Cool meat mixture and freeze in 8-cup container.

To Prepare:  Thaw beef.  Prepare noodles according to package directions.  Heat beef in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring constantly until bubbly.  Serve meat over noodles.

Name: Herbed Chicken
Instructions:
Place chicken in a 1-gallon freezer bag.  In a small bowl, combine the remaining ingredients, except rice.  Pour over the chicken and freeze.

To Prepare:  Thaw chicken mixture.  Preheat oven to 350°.  Place mixture in a 9"x13" baking dish coated with nonstick cooking spray.  Bake, covered, for 1-1/4 hours.  Serve over rice.

Name: Slow-Cooker Fall Pork Roast
Instructions:
Place all ingredients in 1-gallon Ziploc bag.  Label and freeze.

To Prepare:  Thaw.  Place all ingredients in slow cooker and cover.  Cook 6 to 8 hours on low.

Name: London Broil in Marinade
Instructions:
Place london broil in 1-gallon bag.  Mix marinade in small bowl and add it to meat.  Label and freeze.  

To Prepare:  Remove meat and pour marinade into small saucepan.  Boil marinade.  Grill meat over medium-hot coals until desired doneness.  Use marinade for basting.  Depending on thickness of meat, this could take up to one hour.

Name: French Stew
Instructions:
Mix all ingredients and bake in slow-cooker for 8 to 10 hours on low.  Allow to cool and freeze.

To Prepare:  Thaw stew and heat until bubbly in a large pot about 30 minutes.

Name: Chili
Instructions:
Cook the ground beef with onions in a large saucepan until brown, about 20 minutes.  Drain and add remaining ingredients.  Bring to a boil; reduce heat.  Cover and simmer on low heat for 2 hours on a back burner or in a slow-cooker on low for 6 hours, stirring occasionally.  Cool and freeze in a 3-cup container.

To Prepare:  Thaw and heat in saucepan until hot and bubbly, about 30 minutes.

Name: French Dip
Instructions:
Douse roast with Worcestershire sauce; seal meat in 1-gallon freezer bag and freeze.

To Prepare:  Thaw and put roast in slow-cooker.  Sprinklle the dip or gravy mix on top.  Cook 6 to 8 hours on low.   Allow roast to sit 20 minutes before slicing.  Serve thin slices of roast in sandwich rolls with bowls of juice for dipping.

Name: Crustless Spinach Quiche
Instructions:
Thaw spinach to remove liquid.  Combine spinach, green onion bulbs, eggs, cottage cheese and cheddar cheese.  Put into a quiche pan or 10" pie plate coated with nonstick cooking spray.  Cover with foil and freeze.  Put crouton crumbs in a 1-quart bag and tape to pie plate.

To Prepare:  Thaw pie and crumbs.  Bake uncovered in a preheated 325° oven for 1 hour, adding crouton crumbs the last 15 minutes.

Name: Slow Cooker Cranberry Pork
Instructions:
Brown roast in Dutch oven over medium-high heat.  Freeze pork loin.  Combine all ingredients but the last three and freeze in small freezer bag taped to the pork loin bag.  

To Prepare:  Thaw.  Mix together all ingredients and pour over roast.  Cover and cook on low for 4 to 6 hours or until meat thermometer reads 160°.  Remove roast and keep warm.

In a saucepan, combine cornstarch, cold water and salt until smooth.  Stir in cooking juices.  Bring to a boil; cook and stir for 2 minutes or until thickened.  Serve with roast.

Name: Old-Fashioned Oatmeal
Instructions:
Combine the oats, water and salt in the slow cooker; stir to combine.  Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours, or overnight, or on high for 2 to 3 hours.

Stir the oatmeal well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk, buttermilk or cream, a sprinkle of toasted wheat germ, brown sugar and a sprinkle of cinnamon.

Blueberry Oatmeal:  Add 1 cup fresh blueberries or thawed and drained frozen blueberries during the last 30 minutes of cooking

Mixed Grain Oatmeal:  Add 1 cup of cooked white or brown rice to oatmeal either at beginning or during the last 30 minutes of cooking.

Name: Cinnamon Apple Oatmeal
Instructions: Combine all the ingredients in the slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours, or overnight, or on high for 2 to 3 hours.  Stir the oatmeal well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk or cream.

Name: Hot Oatmeal and Rice
Instructions: Combine all the ingredients in the slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours or overnight.  Stir the cereal well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk, soy milk or light cream and honey.

Name: Overnight Steel-Cut Oatmeal
Instructions:
Combine the oats and water in the slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 8 to 9 hours, or overnight, until tender.  Stir the oatmeal well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk or cream and brown sugar or maple syrup.

Overnight Nutty Steel-Cut Oatmeal: Stir in 1/4 cup toasted almonds or other nut at the end of cooking.

Name: Creamy Rice Porridge with Raisins
Instructions: Combine all ingredients in slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low until tender and creamy, 6 to 8 hours or overnight.  Stir the porridge well and serve straight from the pot with no embellishments.

Name: Creamy Cornmeal Porridge
Instructions: Combine all ingredients in slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours or overnight.  Stir a few times with a whisk or wooden spoon, if possible, during cooking.  Stir the porridge well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with a pat of butter, milk and a sprinkle of tasted wheat germ; or stir in cream cheese or mascarpone and top with berries.

Name: Sweet Breakfast Grits
Instructions: Combine the grits, water and salt in slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours or overnight.  Stir the grits a few times during cooking with a whisk and stir in the honey just before serving.  Stir well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk and sliced fruit or berries.

Name: Millet Porridge with Dates
Instructions: Combine the millet, water and salt in the slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours or overnight.  Stir a few times with a whisk during cooking.  Turn the cooker to high and stir in the milk and dates; cover and cook until hot, 5 to 10 minutes.  Stir the porridge well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk and honey.

Name: Cracked Wheat Porridge
Instructions: Place the cracked wheat in a dry skillet and toast over medium heat until you can just smell the aroma, about 5 minutes.  Combine the wheat, water and salt in slow cooker.  Cover and cook until tender on low for 7 to 9 hours (the cracked wheat will take longer to cook than the bulgar) or overnight or on high for 2-1/2 to 3 hours.  Stir a few times with a whisk during cooking.  Scoop into bowls.  Servew with milk and brown sugar or honey.

Name: Your Own Blend Overnight Porridge
Instructions: Combine all the ingredients in the slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 8 to 9 hours or overnight until tender.  Stir well and scoop into bowls.  Serve with milk or cream and brown sugar or maple syrup.

Name: Roasted Vegetable Broth
Instructions:
Preheat the oven to 400°.  Place the leeks, onions, garlic, celery, carrots, squash and bell pepper in a large bowl and toss with oil to lightly coat.  Roast in the oven on a baking sheet until caramelized, 50 to 60 minutes.

Place the roasted vegetables in the slow cooker along with the chard, lentils, parsley, tomatoes and bay leaf and add cold water to cover by 2 to 3 inches.  Cover and cook on high until hot, about 1 hour.  Turn the cooker to low and cook 4 to 6 hours or more.

Uncover and let cool to lukewarm.  Set a large colander lined with a double layer of cheesecloth or a fine-mesh strainer over a large bowl and pour the broth through to strain.  Press the vegetables to extract all the liquid.  Discard the vegetables.  Season with salt.  The broth is ready for use and can be refrigerated for up to 1 week.  Or pour into airtight plastic freezer storage containers, leaveing 2 inches at top to allow for expansion and freeze for 3 to 4 months.

Name: Old-Fashioned Stewed Tomatoes
Instructions: Dip each tomato in boiling water and transfer to a double layer of paper towels.  Slip off the skin and halve the tomato; squeeze out the seeds and cut out the core.  Put tomatoes, onion, celery, bell pepper, sugar, basil and bay leaf in the slow cooker.  Cover and cook on low for 8 to 10 hours.  Remove the bay leaf, season with salt and pepper and stir in the lemon juice.  Stir in the butter until melted.  Serve hot.

Name: Double-Corn Spoonbread
Instructions:
Whisk together milk, cornmeal and salt in a large saucepan over high heat until mixture comes to a boil.  Reduce the heat to a simmer and cook until thickened, about 1 minute.  Stir in the butter until melted, the corn and hot pepper sauce.  Sprinkle with the baking powder and whisk in the eggs until completely smooth.  Fold in the cheese.

Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray.  Pour in the batter.  Cover and cook on high until the spoonbread looks set but is not quite firm, 3 to 3-1/2 hours.  Serve immediately, scooped onto plates.

Name: Polenta
Instructions:
Whisk the water, polenta and salt together in slow cooker for a few seconds.  Cover and cook on high for 30 minutes to 1 hour to heat the water.  

Stir again, cover, turn the cooker to low and cook for about 5 hours, stirring occasionally with a wooden spoon.  The polenta will thicken quite quickly after 2 hours, sort of expand magicalliy in the cooker and look done, but it will need the extra time to cook all the grains evenly.  At 5 hours, taste and make sure the desired consistency has been reached and all the grains are tender.  The longer the polenta cooks, the creamier it will become.  When done, it will be smooth, very thick (yet pourable) and a wooden spoon will stand up by itself without falling over.  The polenta will be fine on low for an additional hour, if necessary.  Add a bit more hot water if it gets too stiff.  Stir befores serving.

To serve as a mound of soft polenta, portion out with an oversized spoon onto plates or into shallow soup bowls.  Top each serving with a pat of butter and sprinkle with some of the cheese.  Serve immediately.

Fried Polenta:  You can also pour out the polenta onto a marble board or into a greased pan to cool; it will stiffen, yet be quite tender.  Refrigerate if not using within a few hours.  Then you can fry slices of it in butter or olive oil and serve alonside roasted meats or egg dishes.

Name: Potato Pancakes
Instructions:
Peel and coarsely grate the potatoes and the onion by hand or in a food processor.  Place them in a tea towel and wring out the excess moisture.  Transfer to a large bowl, add the eggs, baking powder, if using and flour and season with salt and pepper.  Stir until well combined.

Heat the oil in a large, heavy skillet over medium-high heat.  With an oversized spoon, drop the batter into the pan and flatten the pancakes slightly with the back of the spoon.  Fry until crisp and golden brown on both sides, turning once, 3 to 5 minutes total.  Drain on paper towels and serve immediately.

Name: Corn Fritter Cakes
Instructions:
Combine the flour, cornmeal, baking powder, salt and pepper in a large bowl.  Make a well in the center and add milk, eggs and melted butter, stirring just until combined.  Fold in the bell pepper and corn with a rubber spatula.  Do not overmix; the batter will have small lumps.

Heat 2 Tbs. of the oil in a griddle or heavy skillet over medium heat.  Using a 1/4-cup measure or large spoon for each fritter cake, pour the batter onto the griddle.  Cook until crispy; the edges should be dark brown and dry and the bottoms golden bron, about 2 minutes.  Turn once, cooking the other side until golden, about 1 minute.  Drain on a double layer of paper towels.  Continue frying the fritter cakes, using 2 Tbs. of oil for each batch.  Serve immediately or keep warm in preheated 250° oven until ready to serve.

Name: Slow Cooker Pot of Beans
Instructions:
Put the beans in a colander and rinse under running water; pick over for damaged beans and small stones.  Transfer to the slow cooker (it must be large enough so that there is plenty of room for them to bubble without spilling over) and cover with 3" cold water.  Soak for 6 to 12 hours and drain.

Add the 10 cups water and make a bouquet with cheesecloth and kitchen twine (for parlsey, bay leaf, thyme, tarragon, peppercorns and garlic.  This is optional).  Add to the cooker.  Cover and cook on high for required time.  The beans need to be covered with liquid at all times to cook properly.  They will transform the water into a liquid called bean liquor.  When done, the beans will be tender and hold their shape rather than fall apart.  Leave whole or gently mash a portion of the beans in the pot, which will thickn them nicely. 

Serve immediately in soup bowls topped with salt and grated cheese, if desired.  Or, let stand in the cooker for 1 hour, uncovered, then transfer the beans, with the liquor, to a covered storage container and refrigerate or freeze.

Kidney Beans: High for 3 hours.    Navy Beans: High for 2-1/2 to 3 hours. 
Pinto Beans: High for 3 hours.  White beans, small:  High for 3 hours.

Name: Boston Baked Beans
Instructions:
Rinse the beans in a colander under cold running water and pick over for damaged beans and small stones.  Transfer to the slow cooker.  Cover with cold water by 2", soak overnight and drain.

Cover the beans with fresh water by 3".  Add the baking soda, cover and cook on high until still undercooked, about 1-1/2 hours.  Drain.  Meanwhile, simmer the salt pork in boiling water for 10 minutes to remove excess salt; drain and rinse under cold running water.  Pat dry and dice.

Combine the drained beans, salt pork, molasses, brown sugar, mustard, salt and pepper in the cooker; stir to mix well.  Push the onion into the center of the beans and add the boiling water; it will cover everything by 1/2".  Cover and cook on hight to bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low and cook until the beans are soft, thick and bubbling, 10 to 12 hours.  Do not stir but you can add more boiling water to keep the beans moist if you need to.  Traditionally, then beans are cooked with the cover off for the last 30 minutes to thickn them to the desired consistency.

Name: Maple Pork and Beans
Instructions:
Rinse the beans in a colander under cold running water; pick over for damaged beans and small stones.  Transfer to the slow cooker and cover with cold water by 2".  Soak 6 to 12 hours and drain.

Cut the rind off the salt pork in once piece with about 1/2" of fat attached; reserve.  Cut the salt pork into strips 1-1/2" long and 1/2" wide and thick.  Simmer the salt pork strips in boiling water for 5 miutes to remove excess salt;  drain and rinse under cold running water.

Add the salt pork, onions, ketchup, maple syrup, brown sugar, mustard, cayenne and cloves to the beans in the cooker; stir to mix well.  Add the boiling water to cover.  Lay the reserved piece of salt pork rind on the top, cover and cook on low for 4 to 6 hours.  Remove the rind, cover and continue to cook the beans on low until the beans are soft, thick and bubbling, another 6 hours.

Name: Marinara Sauce
Instructions:
Over medium heat in a medium-size skillet, heat 3 Tbs of the oil, then cook the onion and garlic, stirring, until softened, about 5 minutes.  Transfer to the slow cooker, add the remaining olive oil, tomatoes, tomato paste and sugar and stir to combine.  Cover and cook on low for 4 to 5 hours.  

Season the sauce with salt and pepper.  If using canned tomatoes, use a hand-held immersion blender to puree the sauce right in the insert; if using fresh, puree with the fine disk of a food mill to remove the tomato skins.  If not serving the sauce with hot pasta immediately, return to the cooker, where it will stay warm on low for a few hours.  The sauce will keep, refrigerated, for up to a week or frozen for 2 months.

Name: Fresh Tomato Sauce
Instructions: Chop the tomatoes coarsely.  Do this by hand; a food processor will chop them too small.  You want pieces about 3/4 to 1" thick.  Transfer the tomatoes to the slow cooker.  Melt the butter over medium heat in a medium-size skillet.  Add the onion and garlic and cook, stirring a few times, until softened but not browned, about 5 minutes.  Scrape into the slow cooker.  Add the 1 tsp of salt and stir well.  Cover and cook on low for 2 to 3 hours.  At the end of the cooking time, stir in the herbs, if you are using them.  Cover and cook for 5 to 10 minutes longer.  Taste for salt and add the sugar, if desired.

Name: Tomato Basil Sauce
Instructions: In a medium-size skillet over medium heat, melt the butter in the olive oil.  Cook the onion, stirring, until softened, about 5 minutes.  Add the garlic and cook, stirring, for 2 minutes.  Transfer to the slow cooker.  Add the tomatoes, wine, sugar, 2 Tbs of the basil and the thyme and stir to combine.  Cover and simmer on high for 2 to 2-1/2 hours.  Season the sauce with salt and pepper and stir in the remaining 2 Tbs. of basil and parsley.  Cover and cook on low for 20 to 30 minutes longer.  Serve the sauce hot.  It will keep, refrigerate, up to a week and frozen for 2 months.

Name: Pizza Sauce
Instructions: Place the tomato paste and sauce, oil, garlic, herbs and 1 Tbs of the sugar in the slow cooker.  Add just enough water to smooth out the sauce.  Cover and cook on low for 10 to 14 hours, stirring occasionally if you can, until thickened.  Taste for sugar, adding more if necessary, then stir in the cheese.  Season with salt and pepper.  Let the sauce cool to room temperature before using.  It iwll keep, refrigerated, up to 4 days.

Name: Macaroni and Cheese
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray.  Combine the milks, egg, salt and pepper in the cookerand whisk until smooth.  Add the cheese and macaroni; gently stir with a rubber spatual to coat evenly with the milk and cheese mixture.  Sprinkle with Parmesan on the top.  Cover and cook on low until the custard is set in the center and pasta is tender, 3-1/2 to 4 hours.  Do not cook more than 4 hours, as the sides will dry out and burn.

Macaroni and Italian Cheese:  For the cheddar, substitute a combination of 1 cup of shredded fontina and 1/2 cup of diced or shreddeed mozzarella.

Macaroni and Blue Cheese:  Add 1/2 cup of crumbled Gorgonzola, Stilton, Roquefort or American blue cheese to the cheddar and macaroni.

Name: Lazy Day Braised Pot Roast
Instructions:
Put the roast in the slow cooker and sprinkle with salt and pepper.  Add the carrots, potatoes, onion and bay leaves.  Pour the water and vinegar over the meat and vegetables.  Cover and cook on low for 6 to 8 hours.  

Transfer the meat and vegetables to a heated platter and cover with aluminum foil.  Turn the cooker to high.  You will have about 3 full cups of liquid.  In a small bowl, mash together the butter with the flour to make a beuree manie.  Add to the hot liquid in the cooker and stir with a whisk until melted and the liquid thickens.  Ladle some over the meat and vegetables and serve the remainder in a bowl.

Name: Hot Fudge Spoon Cake
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with butter-flavor nonstick cooking spray.  In a medium-size bowl, whisk together the flour, ground chocolate, sugar, baking powder and salt.  Make a well in the center, add the milk, butter and vanilla, stir the liquid ingredients until well blended and continue stirring in widening circles gradually incorporating the dry ingredients until you have a smooth batter.  It will be thick.  Spread evenly in the cooker.

To make the topping, combine all ingredients in another medium-size bowl and whisk until smooth.  Gently pour over the batter in the cooker; do not stir.  Cover and cook on high until puffed and the top layer is set, 2 to 2-1/4 hours.

Name: Chocolate Peanut Butter Pudding Cake
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray.  In a medium-size bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa, sugar, baking powder and salt.  Make a well in the center, add the milk, oil and vanilla and stir until well blended; continue stirring in widening circles, gradually incorporating the dry ingredients, until you have a smooth batter.  Stir in the peanut butter (warm it in the microwave if thick and sticky from refrigeration); the batter will be thick.  Stir in the chocolate chops.  Spread evenly in the cooker.

To make the topping, in another medium-size bowl, combine the cocoa and sugar; pour in the boiling water and whisk until smooth.  Gently pour over the batter in the cooker; do not stir.  Cover and cook on high until puffed and the top layer is set, 2 to 2-1/4 hours.

Turn off cooker and let stand, covered, for at least 30 minutes before serving.  To serve, scoop the cake into individual bowls.  Add a scoop of ice cream alongside the cake.  Spoon some of the fudgy pudding over the cake and ice cream and serve.

Name: Lemon Buttermilk Sponge Pudding
Instructions:
Coat slow cooker in nonstick cooking spray.  In a medium-size bowl, whisk together the sugar, flour and salt.  Make a well in the center, pour in the buttermilk, lemon juice, oil and amaretto and stir until well blended; continue stirring in widening circles, gradually incorporating the dry ingredients, until you have a smooth batter.  In a small abowl, whisk the egg yolks until plae, then whisk into the batter.

In a medium-size bowl, using an electric mixer, beat the egg whites until stiff but not dry.  Gently whisk about 1/3  of the egg whites into the batter.  Add the remaining egg whites and fold in gently with a rubber spatula.  Pour the batter into the cooker.  Cover and cook on high until the cake is puffed and the top is set, 1-1/2 to 2 hour; it will be browned around the edges.

Turn off cooker and let stand, covered, for at least 30 minutes before serving.  To serve, scoop the warm cake and the pudding-lide sauce into individual bowls.  Top with fresh berries if desired.

Name: Tapioca Pudding
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray.  Combine the milk, sugar, tapioca and vanilla in cooker.  Stir well with a whisk.  Cover and cook on low until the milk is absorbed, the pudding thickened and most of the tapioca balls are completely transparent, about 1-1/2 hours.  Some of them will still have the white dot at their centers; that is okay.  While cooking, the milk will be gently bubbling.

Beat the egg in a cup or small bowl.  Stir the tapioca thoroughly to break up any clumps.  Spoon a few Tbs of hot tapioca into the egg and beat well; pour the mixture into the cooker and stir well with a spoon or spatula to combine.  Cover and cook on low for another 30 minutes.

Turn off cooker and let pudding cool, partially covered, for 30 minutes.  Serve warm or pour into individual bowls, cover and chill.  Serve plain or with fruit or whipped cream on top.  Store, covered, in the refrigerator.

Name: Indian Pudding
Instructions:
In a medium-size saucepan, heat 2-3/4 cups of the milk over medium heat.  In a small bowl, combine the remaining 1/2 cup milk with the cornmeal and whisk until smooth.  Pour the cornmeal mixture into the hot milk, whisking constantly.  Cook until it begins to thicken, stirring constantly to avoid lumps.  Whisk in molasses, brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, baking soda, salt and vanilla.  Beat the whole egg and yolk together in a small bowl; add a spoonful of the hot cornmeal mixture and beat well to avoid curdling.  Add another spoonful of the hot mixture, stir, then pour the egg mixture into the saucepan and whisk to combine.  Remove from the heat.

Grease the slow cooker with 1 Tbs. butter.  Pour the cornmeal pudding mixture into the cooker and stir in the remaining 2 Tbs. butter until melted.  Pour in the light cream in a circular motion; do not stur.  Cover and cook on low until the pudding is set, 8-1/2 to 9 hours.  Serve warm, spooned into individual bowls.

Name: Old-Fashioned Applesauce Cake w/ Walnuts
Instructions:
Line the bottom of the slow cooker with a round of parchment paper.  Coat the paper and sides of teh cooker, 1/3 of the way up, with nonstick cooking spray or grease with butter.  

In a medium-size bowl, whisk together the flour, brown sugar, spices, baking soda, baking powder and salt.  In a small bowl, combine the applesauce, buttermilk, melted butter and egg; beat until smooth.  Add the applesauce mixture to the dry ingredients and beat until smooth and fluffy.  Stir in the walnuts.  Spread the batter evenly in the cooker.  Cover and cook on high until puffed and a cake tester inserted into the center comes out clean, 2-1/4 to 2-1/2 hours.  

Turn the cooker off, remove the lid and let stand for 30 minutes to cool.  To remove the cake, run a knife around the inside edge of the cooker and lift it out with a large rubber spatula.  Cut into small wedges and serve warm or at room temperature.

Name: Carrot Cake
Instructions:
Line the bottom of the slow cooker with a round of parchment paper.  Coat the paper and sides of cooker, 1/3 way up, with nonstick cooking spray or butter.

In a medium-size bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, spices, baking powder, baking soda and salt.  In a small bowl, combine the water, oil and eggs, beating until smooth.  Add the liquid ingredients to the dry, beating until smooth and fluffy.  Stir in the carrots and pineapple.  Spread the batter evenly in the cooker.  Cover and cook on high until puffed and a cake tester inserted into center comes out clean, 2-1/4 to 2-1/2 hours.

Turn the cooker off, remove the lid and let stand for 30 minutes to cool.  To remove the cake, run a knife around the inside edge of the cooker and lift it out with a large rubber spatula.  Place it on a small serving plate and cut into small wedges.  Serve warm or at room temperature.

Name: Banana Cake with Pineapple
Instructions:
Line the bottom of the slow cooker with a round of parchment paper.  Coat the paper and sides of cooker, 1/3 of the way up, with nonstick cooking spray or butter.  In a medium-size bowl, combine the oil and sugar.  Beat hard with a whisk or electric mixer until light colored and creamy, about 1 minute.  Add the eggs and vanilla and beat again until well combined.  Add the mashed bananas and beat until smooth.  Add the flour, baking soda and salt and stir to combine.  Beat well to make a creamy, well-blended batter.  Fold in the pineapple and spread the batter evenly in the cooker.  Cover and cook on high until the top is firm to the touch and a cake tester inserted into the center comes out clean, 2-1/4 to 2-1/2 hours.

Turn the cooker off, remove the lid and let stand for 15 minutes to cool.  To remove the cake, run a knife around the inside edge of the cooker and lift it out with a large rubber spatula.  Let cool on a rack.  Wrap the cake tightly in plastic wrap and chill for 8 hours or up to 3 days before serving.

Name: Cornbread with Green Chiles and Corn
Instructions:
Line the bottom of the slow cooker with a round of parchment paper.  Coat the paper and the sides of the cooker, 1/3 of the way up, with nonstick cooking spray or butter.  Whisk together the flour, sugar, cornmeal, baking powder and salt in a medium-size bowl.  Make a well in the center and add the milk, eggs, oil and butter.  With a large spoon or dough whisk, give a few vigorous strokes to blend the liquid and dry ingredients.  Stir in the corn and chiles carefully, making sure not to overmix.  Spread the batter evenly in the cooker.  Cover and cook on high until a cake tester comes out clean, 2-1/4 to 2-1/2 hours.

Turn the cooker off, remove the lid and let stand for 30 minutes to cool.  To remove the cornberad, run a knife around the iniside edge of the cooker and lift it out with a large rubber spatula.  Cut into pieces and serve with butter.

Name: Orchard Crumble
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray or grease with butter.  To make the fruit mixture, put the fruit in the cooker; sprinkle with the cinnamon, sugar and cornstarch and toss to coat the fruit.  Cover and cook on high for 30 minutes.  

Meanwhile, make the topping.  Combine the flour, rolled oats, brown sugar and cinnamon in a small bowl or food processor.  Cut in the butter with two knives or your fingertips or pulse to make coarse crumbs.  After 30 minutes, spread the topping evenly over the gruit, leaving a 1/2" border without topping to prevent burning.  Cover, set to low and cook until the fruit is tender, 2-1/2 to 3-1/2 hours.  Test by sticking a knife into the center of the crumble; when it passes through the fruit with little resistance, the crumble is done.  Uncover and let cool for 10 minutes before serving.  If desired, top each serving with ice cream or whipped cream.

Name: Peach Crumble
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray or grease with butter.  Put the fruit in the cooker, cover and cook on high for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, make the topping.  Combine the rolled oats, flour, brown sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg and salt in a medium-size bowl and cut in the butter with two knives or your fingertips.  Or combine the dry ingredients in a food processor and cut in the butter with a few pulses.  After 30 minutes, spread the topping evenly over the fruit, leaving a 1/2" border without topping to prevent burning.  Cover, set to low and cook until the fruit is tender, 2-1/2 to 3 hours.  Test by sticking a knife into the center of the crumble; when it passes through the fruit with little resistance, the crumble is done.  Uncover and let cool for 10 minutes before serving.  If desired, top each serving with ice cream or whipped cream

Name: Applesauce
Instructions:
Put the apples in the slow cooker and toss with the lemon juice.  If the apples seem unusually dry, add the water to the cooker.  Cover and cook until the apples are extremely tender and falling apart, on high for 3 to 3-1/2 hours or on low for 5 to 6 hours.

Puree the cooked apples in a food processor or in the cooker with a handheld immersion blender or pass them through a food mill fitted with a medium or large blade.  Add sugar to taste, if desired.  Serve immediately or refrigerate and serve cold.  The applesauce will keep, tightly covered, for 2 weeks in the fridge.

Cinnamon Applesauce:  Put one 4 to 6" cinnamon stick in the cooker along with the apples.  After cooking, discard the cinnamon stick before pureeing the apples.

Name: Apple Butter
Instructions:
Coat the slow cooker with nonstick cooking spray.  Fill with the apples, almost to the top; the exact amount is not critical.  As you load in the apples, sprinkle with sugar in layers.  Cover and let stand at room temperature all day; the apples will exude some of their own juice and collapse slightly.  If you want to skip this step, just add the apple juice.

Add the spices and salt and toss the apples with a large wooden spoon.  Cover and cook on low for 10 to 12 hours or overnight.  In the morning, remove the lid and let the apple butter cook an additionaly 2 to 8 hours on low to read the desired thickness.  

Turn off the cooker and let cool to room temperature in the crock.  Transfer to a blender or food processor or use a handheld immersion blender right in the crock and puree the butter until completely smooth.  Scrape with a rubber spatula into spring-top glass jars (or use screw tops with new lids).  Store, covered, in the refrigerator for up to 2 months.  Or transfer to small plastic storage containers and freeze for up to 3 months.  Serve cold or at room temperature.

Name: Pumpkin Puree
Instructions:
Put all the ingredients in the slow cooker and stir with a spatual until well mixed.  Don't worry if there are some lumps in the sugar; they will melt into the butter during cooking.  Use the spatula to scrape down the sides.  Cover and cook on high for 2 hours, stirring occasionally.

Remove the lid and let cook on high for an additional 30 minutes to 1 hour to reach the desired thickness.  Turn off the cooker and let the pumpkin butter cool to room temperature in the crock.  Scrape with a rubber spatula into spring-top glass jars (or use screw tops with new lids).  Store, covered, in the refrigerator for up to 6 weeks.  Or transfer to small plastic storage containers and freeze for up to 3 months.  Serve cold or at room temperature.

Name: Peach Jam
Instructions:
Peel the peaches by dipping them into a pan of boiling water to loosen the skin, then immediately cool them by holding under cold water.  The skins will slip off.  Remove the pits.  In a large bowl, coarsely crush by hand with a potato masher or pulse a few times in a food processor; you'll have about 5 cups of pulp.  Combine the peaches and lemon juice in the slow cooker; sprinkle with pectin, if using.  Let stand for 20 to 30 minutes.

Stir in the sugar.  Cover and cook on low for 2-1/2 hours, stirring twice.  Remove the lid, turn the cooker to high and cook 2 to 3 hours longer, until the jam achieves the desired consistency.  Ladle the warm jam into clean spring-top glass gars (or use screw tops with new lids); let stand until cool.  Store, covered, in the refrigerator for up to 2 months.  Or spoon into small plastic storage containers and freeze for up to 3 months.

Name: All-Purpose Cooked Beans
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients in a very large pot.  Bring to a boil, uncovered, then reduce the heat to low or medium-low and simmer gently, partially covered, according to the recommended cooking time.

Bean cooking time
Black (turtle):  Soak overnight.  Cook 1 hour
Kidney:  Soak overnight.  Cook 1-1/2 to 2 hours
Pinto: Soak overnight.  Cook 1-1/2 to 2 hours
White (Great Northern, Navy):  Soak overnight.  Cook 1 hour

You can also cook beans in a slow cooker, on low for 16 to 20 hours or on high fo 7 to 9 hours;  if cooking on high, check the beans a couple of times so you can add more liquid if needed.

Name: Maple Morning Polenta
Instructions:
Combine water, milk, cornmeal and salt in a medium-size saucepan, stirring briskly to combine.  Cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, until mixture reaches a boil, about 10 minutes.

Reduce heat to low.  Cook 3 to 5 minutes, stirring frequently, until mixture thickens.  Remove from heat.  Stir in pancake syrup and butter; ladle into bowls.  Top with additional syrup and sprinkle with raisins just before serving.

Name: Couscous with Peaches
Instructions:
In a small saucepan, heat reserved peach liquid and milk to simmering.  Add couscous, butter, nutmeg and brown sugar to pan; stir to combine.  Remove from heat; let sit until liquid is absorbed, about 5 to 10 minutes.  Top servings with sliced peaches and a dab of brown sugar.

Note:  If you don't want to used canned peaches, peel and slice 2 fresh peaches and combine 1 cup orange juice with 1 cup milk for the liquid in the recipe.

Name: Easy Granola
Instructions:
Preheat oven to 325°.  Grease 3 large baking sheets with nonstick cooking spray.  In a very large bowl, combine oats, flour, cinnamon, nutmeg and whatever "goodies" you are using.  Mix well.

Combine oil and honey in a 2-cup glass measuring cup.  Mircrowave on high for 2 to 3 minutes until hot.  Pour over dry ingredients and mix well.  Spread mixture over prepared baking sheets; bake until light to medium brown, 15 to 20 minutes.  If you have a convection oven, bake all 3 pans at the same time.  Otherwise, it's best to bake each pan individually on the center rack of oven.

Let granola cool.  It will break up somewhat as you transfer it to a storage container.  Store in an airtight container up to 4 weeks.

Name: Short-cut Pancakes
Instructions:
Combine all ingredients except vegetable oil in a large bowl, whisking lightly until everything is mostly combined (a few lumps are ok).

Lightly grease a skillet or frying pan.  Heat skillet over medium heat until a drop of water sizzles when flicked onto skillet.

Spoon about 1/2 cup batter onto skillet for each pancake.  

For waffles:  Prepare batter as directed above; cook in a hot, well-greased waffle iron for 3 to 4 minutes per waffle.

Name: Crepes
Description: Make-ahead if wanted.  Can be kept in refrigerator for up to one week.
Instructions:
Combine first 7 ingredients in a large bowl to form a thin batter.  Spray a large skillet with nonstick cooking spray.  Place skillet over medium heat for a few minutes.  Pour batter smoothly into hot skillet to make 6" round pancakes.  Tilt the pan a little to spread the batter out as needed; these pancakes should be very thin.  Cook until edges start to dry and curl up a little, 30 to 60 seconds.  Flip and cook pancakes for 20 to 30 seconds on other side.  Remove pancakes from pan while bottom is still pale.

Immediately butter pancakes with the end of a stick of butter.  Sprinkle each pancake with about 2 Tbs. confectioners' sugar and roll up.  Keep pancakes warm in a low oven until ready to serve.  Before serving, top with fruit and sprinkle with an additional Tbs of confectioners' sugar.

Name: Chicken and Apple Sandwiches w/ Cheese
Instructions: Preheat oven to 350°.  Grease a large baking sheet with nonstick cooking spray.  Spread butter on 1 side of each slice of bread.  Arrange 4 bread slices onto prepared baking sheet, butter sides down.  Divide chicken evenly among the 4 bread slices on pan and top each evenly with cheese and apple slices.  Top with remaining bread slices, butter sides up.  Bake for 10 mintues, then flip sandwiches and bake until crispy and golden, about 10 more minutes.  Cut sandwiches in half and serve immediately.

Name: Crunchy Baked Chimichangas
Description: Can be frozen.  Reheat 2 minutes in microwave.
Instructions: Preheat oven to 400°.  Combine chicken, picante sauce, cheese, green onions, cumin, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, pepper and oregano in a medium-size bowl.  Divide mixture evenly among center of tortillas.  Fold opposite sides of tortillas over filling, then roll up from the bottom and place, seam sides down, onto a baking sheet.  Brush with melted butter.  Bake until golden brown, about 25 minutes.  Garnish with additional cheese and green onions; serve salsa on side

Name: Refried Beans
Instructions: Place beans and water in a large pot.  Soak overnight.  Drain beans with a colander and rinse thoroughly.  Add 2 cups fresh water to pot; stir in bacon grease, if using, and next 3 ingredients.  Bring to a boil.  Cover and reduce heat to low.  Simmer 5 to 6 hours, stirring occasionally.  Beans are done when they are very soft.  Add butter to beans and mash well.  Serve with taco chips, tortillas or rice.

Name: Chicken Pot Pie with Cheesy Biscuit Topping
Instructions:
Microwave vegetables on high for 2 minutes to begin to thaw.  In a large heavy skillet, melt 2 Tbs butter over medium-high heat.  Add onion; cook until soft and slightly brown, stirring occasionally.  Add slightly frozen vegetables and cook until heated through, 5 to 7 minutes.  Transfer to a bowl and set aside.

Melt remaining 2 Tbs butter in same skillet over medium heat.  Add chicken and cook through, stirring a few times.  Reduce heat to medium-low.  Add flour, salt, pepper, thrym and dried basil, stirring to coat chicken.  Quickly add broth and cook until mixture begins to thicken.  Add sour cream and mix until combined.  Return vegetables to the skillet and stir.  Reduce heat to low and let cook slowly for a few minutes while you prepare the biscuit topping.  

Preheat oven to 400°.  Coat a 9"x13" casserole dish with nonstick cooking spray.  To prepare topping, in a large bowl, combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, thyme, 1 Tbs basil and pepper.  Add shortening and blend with yoru fingertips or a pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse meal.  Add cheese; toss to combine.  Add beaten eggs and enough milk to form a very soft, wet dough.

Pour filling into prepared casserole dish.  Spoon biscuit mixture in clumps evenly over top of casserole until filling is covered.  If your casserole dish seems very full, put a baking sheet until it in oven.  Bake until biscuit dough is puffed and filling is bubbling, 25 to 35 minutes.

Name: Chicken Cacciatore
Instructions: Layer onion over bottom of a 4 to 6-quart slow cooker.  Add chicken pieces to cooker.  Combine next 12 ingredients and red pepper, if using; pour over chicken in cooker.  Cover and cook on low 7 to 9 hours or on high 3 to 4 hours.  Serve over pasta or rice.

Name: Curried Chicken and Rice Casserole
Instructions: Preheat oven to 350°.  Melt butter in a large skillet over medium-high heat.  Add celery, onion, carrots and apple; cook, stirring a few minutes.  Add next 7 ingredients; stir until well combined.  Pour mixture into a 8" square casserole dish.  Sprinkle with additional curry powder, if desired.  Bake 45 minutes or until bubbly and rice is tender.

Name: Mushroom Chicken
Instructions:
Preheat oven to 350°.  Grease a 9"x13" casserole dish.  Remove skin from chicken pieces.  Place chicken in prepared dish so that all pieces fit in a single layer.

Melt butter in a medium-size skillet over medium heat.  Add onion and cook until it begins to soften, stirring occasionally.  Sprinkle with flour, stir.  Add broth and curry powder; simmer until mixture begins to thicken.  Add mushrooms and cheese, stirring until cheese blends in.  Pour sauce evenly over chicken.  Bake until chicken is cooked through, about 1 hour.

Name: Meatloaf
Instructions: Preheat oven to 400°.  Combine meatloaf ingredients in large bowl.  Mix well, using a large spoon.  Press mixture into an 8" square casserole dish.  Combine sugar, ketchup, and mustards in a medium-size bowl until well mixed and drizzle evenly over top of meatloaf in pan.  Bake for 1 hour.

Name: Chili Corn Pone Pie
Instructions:
Preheat oven to 350°.  Preheat a large heavy skillet over medium-high heat until hot.  Add ground beef and cook until no longer pink.  Remove beef from skillet; add onion to skillet.  Cook onion until it begins to soften, 3 to 5 minutes.  Add remaining filling ingredients; stir well to combine.  Simmer until heated through, 5 to 10 minutes.

In a medium-size bowl, combine cornmeal, flour, salt, baking powder and baking soda.  Add beaten egg, milk and oil to flour mixture; mix well to form a soft dough.  Spread meat mixture over the bottom of a 9" pie pan.  Drop tablespoonfuls of the corn bread mixture all over the top of the pie, distributing it as evenly as possible.  Sprinkle cheese across the top.  Bake 45 minutes, or until cheese is flecked with brown and filling starts to bubble out the sides.

Name: Boston Baked Beans
Instructions:
Soak beans overnight in cold water to cover.  Transfer beans and soaking water to a large saucepan; bring to a simmer over low heat.  Continue to simmer until beans begin to soften, about 1 hour.  Drain and reserve liquid.  Preheat oven to 325°.

In a large skillet over medium heat, cook bacon and onion until both begin to brown, about 10 minutes.  Combine drained beans, browned bacon and onion and remaining ingredients in an ovenproof pan (cast-iron will work) and stir to combine.  Pour in enough of the reserved bean cooking water to cover beans, about 3 cups.  Cover pan with aluminum foil or a lid.  Bake, stirring every hour or so, until beans are tender, 2 to 3 hours.  Remove lid about halfway through cooking and add more liquid if necessary to prevent beans from becoming dry.

Name: Toasty Tuna Melt Casserole
Instructions: Preheat oven to 400°.  Grease a 9"x13" casserole dish.  Pour bread cubes into dish.  In a large bowl, whisk together tuna, onion, melted butter, pepper, curry powder, milk and eggs.  Pour tuna mixture over top of bread cubes in dish.  Using clean hands or a flat spatula, press bread cubes into the liquid so that most of the bread becomes dampened.  Sprinkle with cheese.  Bake until casserole starts to puff up, cheese has melted, and bread cubes have some browned, crunchy-looking edges, 20 to 30 minutes.

Name: Spinach-Cheddar Quiche
Instructions: Preheat oven to 350°.  Whisk together eggs, half and half, mayonnaise, flour, mustard, salt, pepper and nutmeg.  Add onion, spinach and cheese; mix thoroughly.  Pour mixture into a prepared pie crust; bake until the filling is set and the top is golden brown, about 45 minutes.

Name: Spinach Frittata
Instructions:
Beat eggs and pepper in a large bowl.  Heat oil over medium heat in a large broiler-proof skillet.  Add onion and garlic; cook until soft, 4 to 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

While onion and garlic saute, preheat broiler.  Add spinach to skillet; cook, stirring occaionsally, until spinach is limp.  Stir in cottage cheese.  Pour egg mixture into skillet.  As eggs begin to set, run a metal spatula around the edge of the skillet, lifting mixture up so that uncooked egg mixture flows underneath.  Continue cooking and lifting until most of the egg mixture is set.  

Place pan under broiler 4 to 6" from heat.  Broil for a few minutes, watching closely, until top of frittata sets.  Cut into wedges and serve immediately.

Name: Spicy Ethiopian Beef in Green Pepper Sauce
Instructions:
Combine 2 chopped green peppers, hot pepper, garlic, ginger, turmeric, salt and pepper in a food processor.  Blend at high speed, scraping down sides as needed, until smooth.  Scoop into a bowl; set aside. 

Finely chop onions.  Place onions in a heavy 10 to 12" skillet and cook over medium-low heat utnil soft and dry, 5 to 6 minutes, stirring often and watching constantly.  When onions begin to brown, add 2 Tbs oil and cook 2 to 3 more minutes, stirring occasionally.  Transfer onions to a bowl.

Heat remaining 2 Tbs oil is same skillet until hot.  Add beef strips, a handful at a time, and cook till brown.  Remove to side once browned.  Once all beef is cooked, return onions to skillet and increase heat to medium-high.  Add green pepper strips, stirring constantly; cook 2 to 3 minutes until strips are soft.  Stir in green pepper puree and bring to a boil.  Return beef and any accumulated juices to green pepper sauce in skillet.  Reduce heat to low, cover partially, and simmer 6 to 8 minutes.

Name: Mexican Tortilla Skillet
Instructions:
Heat a large skillet over high heat until hot.  Add ground beef, garlic and taco seasoning.  Cook until beef is browned.  While beef is browning, slice tortillas into 1" squares.  A pizza cutter or scissors works well for this.

Add tomatoes, salsa and tortillas to skillet and cook for 5 minutes over medium heat.  Add water if it seems a little dry.  Once this is heated through, sprinkle ceese over top and cover for a few minutes.  Once cheese is melted, it is ready to serve.  Sprinkle with green pepper.

Name: Thai Chicken Curry
Instructions: Place a heavy skillet or wok over medium heat.  Add milk and bring to a simmer.  Cut chiken into bite-size pieces while you wait.  Once coconut milk begins to simmer, add curry paste, fish sauce and sugar and whisk until well mixed.  When mixture begins to boil, add chicken and cook through, stirring every few minutes.  This will take 10 or more minutes, depending on the size of your skillet.  You can put a lid on your skillet to speed cooking.  Near the end of cooking, add butter and jalapeno.  Stir to incorporate melted butter.  Serve with rice.

Name: West African Peanut Chicken
Instructions:
Heat oil over high heat for 3 to 4 minutes in a deep pot or large heavy skillet.  Add chicken pieces, half at a time and fry on both sides until nicely browned.  Once all chicken pieces are cooked, set aside in a covered bowl to keep warm.  

Add onions and garlic in same pot; cook until onions are soft and begin to brown, stirring occaisonally.  Add pureed tomatoes and 1 cup water; reduce heat to medium, bring to a simmer and let simmer for a few minutes.

Return chicken to pot.  Stir in peanut butter.  Mixture will look clumpy for a minute, but will mix nicely once it heats up.  Add cayenne pepper, black pepper and salt.  Simmer over low heat 10 to 15 minutes.  Stir in diced green pepper and tomatoes; simmer for 3 to 4 more minutes.

Name: Chicken Fajitas
Instructions:
Heat 1 Tbs. oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat until hot.  Add chicken strips and cook, stirring a couple of times, until almost cooked through, 5 to 6 minutes.  Add half of fajita sasoning and water, mix well and let chicken finish cooking.  Transfer chicken to a bowl; cover to keep warm.

Heat remaining Tbs of oil in skillet until hot.  Add onions and peppers; cook, without stirring, utnil tender and some caramelized brown bits begin to show up in pan, 3 to 4 minutes.  Stir; add garlic and remaining fajita seasoning.  Let cook abrou 2 more minutes.  Stir vegetables into seasoned chicken (or serve vegetables separately).  Serve the fajita mixture on warm tortillas with salsa and sour cream on the side, if using.

Name: Fajita Seasoning
Instructions: Combine all ingredients in a small bowl.  Set aside and use just as you would the seasoning packet that comes in taco kits at the store.

Name: Pork Carnitas
Instructions: Trim pork of excess fat; cut into 2 to 3" cubes.  Combine pork cubes in a large heavy pot with soda, water and salt.  Bring to a simmer over high heat, then reduce heat to low and continue to simmer, uncovered, for 2 hours.  Do not stir.  After 2 hours, turn heat up to medium and cook, covered, until all liquid has evaporated and pork fat has rendered, about 45 minutes.  Stir a few times, just often enough to keep pork from sticking hard to bottom of pan.  If it starts to stick, add a little more water as you complete cooking time.  When done, pork will be brown on both sides, and just a little liquid fat will remain in pot.  Pork will be so tender that it will fall apart at the touch.  Serve pork in warm tortillas with salsa and sour cream or guacamole.

Name: Hearty Beef and Noodles
Instructions:
Heat 2 Tbs olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.  Add onions and cook, stirring occasionally, until some onions start to get a little browned, about 10 minutes.  Remove onions to a bowl.  In a bag, combine flour, thyme, salt and pepper.  Add beef cubes and toss well to coat with flour.  Remove cubes from bag, shaking off any excess flour.  

In same skillet, heat remaining 2 Tbs oil over medium heat until hot; add beef and brown on all sides.
